Ci torneremo.!!

title: Interesting side trip
content: Do not follow the map here. It will lead you to a wrong direction. A very nice place to relax. The water is cool and clear.

title: Different afternoon out
content: I came by accident to these rapids.Went for a ride and ended up there.What I like was the water temperature was so much cooler than the Kampopt River..A very rugged strip with plenty of places to stop and enjoy and go for a swim.Many locals use this area on the weekend.

title: Fun afternoon by the river
content: Must admit, I was confused when the Tuc-Tuc driver dropped us at the side of the road and pointed to some trees.  I was expecting a pretty river with some snack places and hammocks to laze around.  Instead, we followed a steep muddy path down to some rocks and fast flowing water.  Not a building in sight.We started off by paddling and eventually surrendered and jumped in with our clothes on (no swimming costumes).Once we were wet we had the most amazing time splashing about in the rapids.  Highly recommended.  Just make sure to pack a swimsuit and a towel.

title: Beautiful, but beware
content: Rent a bungalow for the afternoon, order some cold beers and one of the sharing dishes off the menu. What more could you want! Whole chicken with fiery chilli sauce, steamed rice and fried vegetables was so tasty. Couple of hours in a hammock then a swim in the rapids. Great day out

title: Relaxing couple of hours
content: These are mesmerizing to watch when the dam is open and water rushes over the boulders. I tubed over them once when I thought the current might be a little lower. Still very dangerous not sure how I remained unhurt. But definitely recommend to watch the sunset by.

title: Memorable tubing trip
content: There are many places along the river where you can choose a covered wooden platform at the water's edge. Women will come and sell food, drinks and fruit. Peaceful surroundings in nature. Beware of the sometimes strong currents if the flow is strong. Great place for a few hours. Takes about 20 minutes by tuk tuk from Kampot.

title: แม่น้ำ Preaek Teuk Chhu
content: Went with my three friends for a little tubing fun. We all had our own motos so we parked two towards the bottom of the rapids.  I would recommend this because its can be a long walk back.  If you head up to the dam you will find a shop/restaurant on the left side of the road.  We rented our tubes with them.  You have to walk through a field to get to the river so you will want some sandals.  Don't go during the dry season or you will be scraping rocks with your butt or having to walk in some parts.  Watch out for the local kids.  They will try to ride down on you and most don't have swim suites.  My friend got a butt in his face.  Wish I had my camera

title: Arcadia tubing
content: แม่น้ำ Preaek Teuk Chhu เดินมาริมแม่น้ำ Preaek Teuk Chhu สายเลือดของเมือง Kampotแถวนี้ยามเยนจะมีผู้คนมาพักผ่อน ออกกำลังกาย แต่บรรยากาศดีมาก สบายๆ ชิวๆ

title: Best during or after wet season
content: This was fantastic and everyone had a ball. The safety instructions were great and the adrenalin rush, followed by the calm of the flowing river made this a great experience.

title: Beautiful
content: Very popular with the locals, busy place and really good to cool down, head further north to see more waterfalls but expect a steep walk. Both very beautiful at the right time of the year

title: less than ordidnary
content: Lovely place. Unfortunately the rapids were too wild for rafting when I was there. Had a lovely riverside meal and a sleep in a hammock instead

title: Road to no where.
content: The place claims to be a "natural" attraction but there remains very little natural about it. The Chinese operators, enemies of nature, of the hydro power infrastructure have stripped the high banks of the mountains up from the water and planted some sort of trees ... the natural forest looks much nicer. Also, at the two check points selling tickets into the place, the operators are very likely to offer a discounted entry price. Foreigners are 2 dollars, and you will get a ticket. If they offer you a 5,000 riel discounted entry fee, and no ticket, the money goes into their pockets and not into the system which one would assume is paying for cleaning and upgrades etc etc. I have nothing against people making a living, but do have a problem with being charged extra for being a foreigner and seeing that money simply go into someone's picket.

title: Dead end
content: You have to pay for the privilege to drive down a public road. Don't bother. It's dirty, crowded and noisey. At weekends it's very popular with locals.  About half a mile before where you pay the toll. Pull off the road climb down through the trees. Where you can clamber onto so rocks. It's got a number of small falls and some great leaping off points into the plunge pools below.

title: Surtout ne pas y aller
content: Nothing here, not worth the trip, mediocre landscape, $2 fee per person. The ticket person will charge you and try not to give you the ticket to keep the money for himself.

title: Tourist
content: Visite des chutes d'eau 13 personnes, pour aller les voir il faut payer 2$ par personne pour au final un barrage hydraulique que l'on ne peut pas visiter. Et absence de chutes d'eau et de rapides eaux vives car le barrage est fermé. Résultat : perte de temps et d'argent qui faut négocier pour se faire rembourser la moitié. Le pire c'est que le gardien savait que le barrage était fermé...On appelle ça du vol.

title: nothing to see!
content: Waste of time, fees, and petrol to get there. Nothing to see,nothing to do, nothing happening there at all.

title: Ne vaut pas le déplacement
content: Having to pay $1 to go and see some water flowing over rocks to me is not a tourist attraction. As for the food stalls that are there, typical touristy rip off.

title: Vous avez dit rapide????
content: Ne vaut vraiment pas le déplacement et la personne qui demande 1 usd sur la route avant l'acces est selon moi une arnaque petite mais quand même je pense q'il y as d'autres choses plus intéressante a Kampot que de voire une riviere sans chutes d'eau.

title: Probably best not to visit in November.
content: Drôles de rapides, plutôt une petite rivière, le garde à l'entrée qui nous fait payer sans nous donner de ticket bien sur, direct dans sa poche. Nous avons payé pour voir une rivière plutôt asséchée puisqu'il y a un barrage en amont!!!

title: Very beautyful River
content: These are not what I'd call rapids. There was a fair amount of water, but hardly any rocks over which it broke. Cool place to have a dip while eating Cambodian food, but not as exciting as we were led to believe.

title: less than ordidnary
content: i am disappointed the River is nice but the people throw all full garbage. Realy beautyfull. Stinking Water.

title: Road to no where.
content: The place claims to be a "natural" attraction but there remains very little natural about it. The Chinese operators, enemies of nature, of the hydro power infrastructure have stripped the high banks of the mountains up from the water and planted some sort of trees ... the natural forest looks much nicer. Also, at the two check points selling tickets into the place, the operators are very likely to offer a discounted entry price. Foreigners are 2 dollars, and you will get a ticket. If they offer you a 5,000 riel discounted entry fee, and no ticket, the money goes into their pockets and not into the system which one would assume is paying for cleaning and upgrades etc etc. I have nothing against people making a living, but do have a problem with being charged extra for being a foreigner and seeing that money simply go into someone's picket.
